Island of Old: Prologue

03/11/2012

Love, death and betrothal in a country fighting for freedom; Nouse's first fiction blog is set in both present and past, charting the struggles of Princess Joan of Wales in the year before her marriage

Image by

By James Bithell

Galloping along the muddy forest track, she could feel the wind grasp and tear at her hair. Her long red skirts; draped across the curve of her horse, wrestled with the mud splatters from the hooves, and trees battered her due to the swiftness of her steed. Her fingers and extremities battled against the biting rain as it cut across her face. Her whole body was cold and aching and was desperate to turn back. She wanted a warm house, a hot meal and a sanctuary; she also knew that it was a lengthy journey that lay ahead of her and that if she turned back now, it would be the end of life as she knew it. A life where bewilderment clung at every corner. A life that was full of fear. A life that would be certainly short lived. She lived in a world of battle scars, scorched land and loss. A world where marriage was intended to bind kingdoms together and where death was a reality. She had to travel onwards.

February 2010

"Come on, it's nearly dark!" Was the shout from up ahead, by Elizabeth to her friends following behind her. She was a short woman no more than 5 foot 4 in stature, reasonably fit and healthy with a slim but definite curve to her body. As her dark her brown hair whipped around her shoulders in the fresh winter air, she turned to see the group of friends lagging behind her at half a pace. "Hurry up!" She yelled "do you want to see it or not?" "Sorry" came the reply from her good friend Paul, "its hard work you know, it's not exactly a typical Sunday stroll!" He had an attractive appearance and a good dress sense for a guy. He was a student at Bangor University studying chemistry and he was, she had to admit, quite a ladies man. He knew everything about her and, in turn, she knew everything about him. They were best friends and each other's worst enemy. She loved the way he talked about all the places he had been and the people he had seen, and he loved how she wasn't afraid to talk to anybody and was so confident and bubbly. He loved her thirst for knowledge and her amazing ability to communicate her words across a page. She was studying for a Welsh History degree and he knew, deep down, that she was very good at what she did and that she would succeed in everything she wanted. He was barely keeping his head above water in his studies and spent most of his time out partying and sleeping with a numerous women, where as she always had her head in a book, she was studious but she still knew how to let her hair down, and boy, did he know it. This was the one fact that he resented. "Well I am sorry, I thought you were up for it, obviously you haven't got the stamina!" "Stamina, I'll show you stamina!" he ran up behind and picked her up and threw her over his shoulder and marched on up the steep bank at the side of the hill. "God Paul, put her down she's not one of your Saturday night girls, she is actually a nice person!" this came from Paul's sister, Fiona who Elizabeth had known since she was small. She was the exact opposite of Elizabeth; she was tall, slim and beautiful. Every man adored her and every girl wanted to be her best friend. She was an air hostess and was extremely well-travelled. She could speak over 5 languages and was a talented dancer. Elizabeth could speak the smallest bit of German from her GCSE year at high school, but that was it. She loved her persona and her elegance but deep down she couldn't help but think that part of her longed to be free. The thing that struck Elizabeth most about Fiona was the fact that she knew exactly how things would fit into her life and she knew exactly how to get it, whereas Elizabeth didn't have a clue, she planned ahead, and that was an understatement, every time she had an idea there was a plan following it, but following it through was a different matter. She didn't have the slightest clue how her life would pan out, but she could dream, it was one of her many talents. Ever since she was small she had a vivid imagination and was forever drawing pictures and as she got older she started writing songs and poems, each one got better and better as she journeyed through her childhood. "Awww they are only messing, leave him be, he's a grown man and fair play to him". The deep voice that said that came from Marcus, Fiona's new man. He was the typical stereotype of "suave and sophisticated" and thought a lot of himself. His boyish good looks and charm made it possible for him to get any woman he wanted and he wasn't shy about spending his cash. He lived "up town" in a brand new, multipurpose penthouse apartment in Chester and worked in a law firm as a highly paid solicitor, soon to be promoted. Protectively, he slid his arm around Fiona's delicate waist and turned to her, kissing her passionately. It was Fiona, who broke off first, "Well, as lovely as that was, my feet hurt, hey Lizzie? How far do we have to go?" "It's not far now, only round the corner". As they approached the service point at the top of the hill, the view was awe inspiring. The mountain tops glistened with fresh snow, casting their magic spell over the whole island. The mist was rising up off the straits, bringing a huge sense of eeriness to the place that Elizabeth loved and treasured so much. As the moon reflected against the water each one felt a tremor of excitement at the sight of the mystical image, portrayed before them. But it was the Meni Bridge which really illustrated the true wonder that held them bewitched as if in a trance. Its high arches were illuminated by thousands of lights, each shining brilliantly in the darkness of the night. It was a moment of complete serenity and enchantment, so much so, that none of the four moved from the spot they were standing. "This is amazing Lizzie, how did you know about this place?" (Elizabeth hated being referred to as 'Lizzie') as she was about to answer Fiona's question , Paul gently put his arm around her shoulders and she couldn't help but feel a slight tingle in the pit of her stomach at his touch. "I have been coming here ever since I was little; my family have lived here for years. This is one of my favourite places to be." "It is pretty spectacular, but I'm freezing my chuff off here, so can we go back to the cottage and have a fine glass of something?" Marcus started to walk back down the hill and was shortly followed by Fiona. Paul leaned over the wall next to Elizabeth and was obviously mesmerised by the sight before him. "It is amazing Iz (she liked that a lot better), but Marcus is right, it is cold so let's go". She was just about to leave when something in the distance caught her eye. She had been told about the island legends since being small, about the druids and about the sacred worship they did. They were remarkably intelligent and it was said that they had healing powers, powers which no one could really understand today. Paul was now further down the path and he turned to see Elizabeth leaning out towards the sea. "You coming?" he shouted but he got no reply. She was deep in thought and as he walked up to her he could see that she wasn't looking out to the sea, she was looking past the sea as if she was looking into another world. He touched her hand, hoping to get a reaction, her fingers were ice cold and her hand was pale against the grey slate of the wall. Almost immediately she became aware of her surroundings. Turning to him with a smile she nodded and he put a comforting arm around her shoulder and pulled her away from the sight of the bridge, just before she left, she took one quick look back and she could have sworn that she saw hoof prints on the ground, emerging from the snow which was, and had been for several minutes, falling gently around her.
